raw_text:
Cars pull down US retail figures
 
 US retail sales fell 0.3% in January, the biggest monthly decline since last August, driven down by a heavy fall in car sales.
 
 The 3.3% fall in car sales had been expected, coming after December's 4% rise in car sales, fuelled by generous pre-Christmas special offers. Excluding the car sector, US retail sales were up 0.6% in January, twice what some analysts had been expecting. US retail spending is expected to rise in 2005, but not as quickly as in 2004.
 
 Steve Gallagher, US chief economist at SG Corporate & Investment Banking, said January's figures were "decent numbers".
 
 "We are not seeing the numbers that we saw in the second half of 2004, but they are still pretty healthy," he added. Sales at appliance and electronic stores were down 0.6% in January, while sales at hardware stores dropped by 0.3% and furniture store sales dipped 0.1%. Sales at clothing and clothing accessory stores jumped 1.8%, while sales at general merchandise stores, a category that includes department stores, rose by 0.9%. These strong gains were in part put down to consumers spending gift vouchers they had been given for Christmas.
 
 Sales at restaurants, bars and coffee houses rose by 0.3%, while grocery store sales were up 0.5%. In December, overall retail sales rose by 1.1%. Excluding the car sector, sales rose by just 0.3%. Parul Jain, deputy chief economist at Nomura Securities International, said consumer spending would continue to rise in 2005, only at a slower rate of growth than in 2004. "Consumers continue to retain their strength in the first quarter," he said. Van Rourke, a bond strategist at Popular Securities, agreed that the latest retail sales figures were "slightly stronger than expected".
llama3.2:1b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January.
Excluding car sales, US retail was up 0.6% in January.
Consumer spending rose slightly, but at a slower rate than in 2004.
Sales at appliance and electronic stores were down.
Clothing and general merchandise stores saw stronger gains.
llama3.2:3b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January due to a decline in car sales, but excluding cars, sales rose 0.6%.
Sales at clothing and general merchandise stores increased, while those at appliance and hardware stores decreased.
Consumer spending is expected to rise in 2005 at a slower rate than in 2004.
gemma2:2b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January, mainly due to a decline in car sales.
Appliance and electronic stores saw declines, while clothing and general merchandise stores saw gains.
Restaurants and grocery stores also saw increases.
Consumer spending is expected to continue growing in 2005 at a slower pace than in 2004.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US retail sales fell by 0.3% in January, but this was not due to car sales (which had risen 4% from December).
Instead, it's because car sales dropped 4%, and this is expected to be the biggest monthly decline since August.
However, overall retail spending is forecast to rise in 2005, only at a slower rate of growth than in 2004.
Note that the text does not provide detailed explanations or specific figures for all aspects mentioned.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January due to a 3.3% drop in car sales following December's 4% rise on pre-Christmas offers.
Excluding cars, US retail sales increased 0.6%, marking twice the projected growth.
Consumer spending is expected to grow but not as quickly as in 2004, with strong gains at clothing and accessories stores offsetting a slight decline in other categories like hardware and furniture.
qwen2.5:3b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January, marking the biggest monthly decline since August and primarily due to a sharp drop of 3.3% in car sales.
Excluding cars, US retail was up 0.6%, better than expected.
Expectations are for growth in 2005 but at a slower pace compared to 2004.
Gallagher from SG Corporate & Investment Banking described January's figures as "decent numbers," noting they are healthier but not on par with second half of 2004.
Sales were down 0.6% at appliance and electronics stores, and sales dropped by 0.3% at hardware stores while furniture store sales fell slightly.
Clothing and accessory stores saw a strong gain of 1.8%, along with department stores which rose 0.9%.
These gains can be attributed to Christmas gift vouchers.
Restaurants, bars, coffee houses experienced a slight increase in sales (0.3%), as did grocery stores (0.5%).
December's overall retail sales rose by 1.1%.
Excluding car sector sales saw only a modest rise of 0.3% in December.
Nomura Securities' Parul Jain predicts continued consumer spending growth in 2005, albeit at a slower pace compared to previous years.
Van Rourke from Popular Securities views January's retail figures as "slightly stronger than expected."
opencoder:1.5b: The text discusses a decline in US retail sales data driven by car sales.
It compares month-to-month changes since last August to predict future growth in the U.S. retail sector.
The text also highlights significant gains and losses from January, including expecations after December's fall in car sales.
A key part of the analysis is that sales at specific categories like appliance and electronic stores have fallen during January.
smollm:1.7b: The US retail sales fell by 0.3% in January, driven down by a heavy fall in car sales.
Excluding the car sector, US retail sales rose by 0.6%.
The 3.3% fall in car sales had been expected, coming after December's 4% rise in car sales, which was fuelled by generous pre-Christmas special offers.
Steve Gallagher, US chief economist at SG Corporate & Investment Banking, said January's figures were "decent numbers".
Sales at appliance and electronic stores were down 0.6%, while sales at hardware stores dropped by 0.3% and furniture store sales increased by 0.1%.
Sales at clothing and clothing accessory stores rose by 0.9%, while sales at general merchandise stores, a category that includes department stores, rose by 0.5%.
Sales at restaurants, bars and coffee shops rose by 0.3%, while grocery store sales were up 0.5%.
In December, overall retail sales rose by 1.1%.
Excluding the car sector, sales rose by slightly stronger than expected.
Van Rourke, a bond strategist at Popular Securities, agreed that the latest retail sales figures were "slightly stronger than expected".
He said consumers continued to retain their strength in the first quarter.
Overall, the US retail sales fell by 0.3% in January, driven down by a heavy fall in car sales.
Excluding the car sector, US retail sales rose by 0.6%.
The 3.3% fall in car sales had been expected, coming after December's 4% rise in car sales, which was fuelled by generous pre-Christmas special offers.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Cars pull down US retail sales by 3.3% in January, driven by a drop from pre-Christmas specials.
Retail spending is expected to rise in 2005 but less so than 2004. appliance and electronics sales fell 0.6%, while hardware and furniture rose 0.1%.
Clothing and accessories saw a 1.8% gain, general merchandise (including department stores) rose 0.9%, and sales at restaurants, bars, and coffee houses increased by 0.3%.
Food retail, excluding the car sector, rose only 0.5%.
December retail sales saw a 1.1% increase, down from 2004's drop of 0.6%.
Consumer spending is expected to rise in 2005 but at a slower rate than 2004.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US retail sector reported a decline of 0.3% in January compared to December, the biggest monthly decrease since August 2004.
Despite heavy falls in car sales, the retail market is expected to increase modestly next year but at a slower pace than in 2004.
The strong increase in consumer spending for gift-giving on Christmas was partly offset by declines in restaurants and grocery stores.
Retail sales rose overall, but excluding car sales, they were down 1.1% in December.
Despite the slower growth rate for retailers in 2005, consumer spendinng is expected to continue to increase at a moderate pace next year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US retail sales fell by 0.3% in January, marking their biggest monthly decline since last August.
Excluding car sales, the retail sales increased 0.6%, twice as much as analysts had been expecting.
US retail spending is expected to rise in 2005, but at a slower pace than in 2004.
Sales at appliance and electronic stores dropped by 0.6%, while sales at hardware stores increased by 0.3% and furniture store sales saw a drop of 0.1%.
Sales at clothing and clothing accessory stores rose by 1.8%, with sales at general merchandise stores up by 0.9%.
This strong growth was partly due to consumers spending gift vouchers they had been given for Christmas.
Sales at restaurants, bars and coffee houses increased by 0.3%, while grocery store sales rose by 0.5% in December.
Excluding the car sector, sales increased by 1.1%.
The US retail sales figures are expected to rise by 0.8% in 2005, which is slightly less than analysts had forecast in their consensus view.
phi:2.7b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January, marking the largest monthly decline since August.
However, excluding the car sector, sales rose by 0.6%.
The strong gains were attributed to consumers spending gift vouchers given for Christmas.
Sales at clothing stores, furniture stores and general merchandise stores saw an increase in January.
In December, overall retail sales rose by 1.1% with only a small rise of 0.3%, excluding the car sector.
Experts predict that consumer spending will continue to rise in 2005 but at a slower rate than in 2004.
orca-mini:3b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January driven down by a heavy fall in car sales, with the 3.3% fall in car sales being the biggest monthly decline since last August.
The sector excluding car sales saw an increase of 0.6% in January, which was twice what some analysts had been expecting.
Steve Gallagher, US chief economist at SG Corporate & Investment Banking said January's figures were "decent numbers".
Sales at appliance and electronic stores were down 0.6%, while sales at hardware stores dropped by 0.3% and furniture store sales dipped 0.1%.
Sales at clothing and clothing accessory stores jumped 1.8%, while sales at general merchandise stores, a category that includes department stores, rose by 0.9%.
These strong gains were in part put down to consumers spending gift vouchers they had been given for Christmas.
hermes3:3b: US car sales fall, causing 0.3% drop in January retail sales; non-car sector up 0.6%.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January, primarily driven by a heavy decline in car sales.
Excluding the car sector, retail sales were up 0.6%.
Sales at appliance and electronic stores, hardware stores, and furniture stores declined, while clothing and general merchandise stores saw gains.
Sales at restaurants, bars, and coffee houses rose, and grocery store sales increased as well.
Both consumer spending and retail sales growth are expected to increase in 2005 but at a slower rate than in 2004.
stablelm2:1.6b: US retail sales declined by 0.3% in January, driven by a decrease in car sales.
The car sector saw its biggest monthly drop since August, following December's increase of 4%.
Excluding the car sector, US retail sales increased by 6%, with clothing and accessory store sales contributing to these gains.
Consumer spending is expected to rise, but at a slower rate compared to November's growth.
Restaurants, bars, coffee houses, and grocery stores also experienced an increase in sales during this time period.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US retail sales decreased by 0.3% in January, marking the largest monthly decline since August 2018, primarily due to a substantial drop in car sales from December's surge (4% increase fueled by pre-Christmas promotions).
Excluding the automotive sector, retail sales increased by 0.6%, exceeding some analysts' expectations.
Overall, 2005 is projected to see slower consumer spending growth than in 2004 but still robust growth.
Appliance and electronics store sales dropped 0.6%, while hardware and furniture stores saw slight decreases of 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.
Conversely, clothing and accessories sales increased by 1.8%, attributed to consumers using Christmas gift vouchers.
General merchandise store sales rose by 0.9%.
Restaurant, bar, and coffee house sales climbed by 0.3%, while grocery sales grew by 0.5%.
December's overall retail sales increased by 1.1%; excluding cars, they rose by just 0.3%.
Economists predict that consumer spending will remain resilient in the first quarter of 2005 but at a more moderate pace than in 2004.
chatgpt-4o-latest: US retail sales fell 0.3% in January, the largest drop since August, mainly due to a 3.3% decline in car sales following a strong December.
Excluding cars, retail sales rose 0.6%, exceeding expectations.
While appliance, hardware, and furniture sales declined slightly, clothing and general merchandise sales saw strong gains, partly due to holiday gift vouchers.
Restaurant and grocery sales also increased.
Analysts expect consumer spending to continue rising in 2005 but at a slower pace than in 2004.
Despite the decline, economists view the figures as relatively strong.
